The '''Group of Seven''' ('''G7''') is an [[inter-governmental|intergovernmental]] political & economic forum consisting of [[Canada]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[United States]]; additionally, the [[European Union]] (EU) is a "non-enumerated member". It is organized around shared values of [[Cultural pluralism|pluralism]], [[liberal democracy]], and [[Representative democracy|representative government]].<ref name="What is the G7">{{Cite web|title=What is the G7?|url=https://www.g7uk.org/what-is-the-g7/|access-date=12 June 2021|website=G7 UK Presidency 2021|language=en-GB|archive-date=25 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211225102211/https://www.g7uk.org/what-is-the-g7/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Report for Selected Countries Subjects|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2018/01/weodata/weorept.aspx?pr.x=34&pr.y=14&sy=2016&ey=2023&scsm=1&ssd=1&sort=country&ds=.&br=1&c=156,158,132,112,134,111,136&s=NGDPD,PPPGDP&grp=0&a=|website=www.imf.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|date=October 2017|title=World Economic Outlook Database|url=https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2017/02/weodata/weoselco.aspx?g=119&sg=All+countries+%2f+Advanced+economies+%2f+Major+advanced+economies+(G7)|publisher=International Monetary Fund. imf.org|at=Major Advanced Economies (G7)}}</ref> G7 members are the major [[Developed country#IMF advanced economies|IMF advanced economies]].

Originating from an ''ad hoc'' gathering of [[finance minister]]s in 1973, the G7 has since become a formal, high-profile venue for discussing and coordinating solutions to major [[list of global issues|global issues]], especially in the areas of trade, security, economics, and [[climate change]].<ref>{{Cite web|author=Paul LeBlanc|title=What is the G7, and what power does it hold?|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/11/politics/g7-summit-explainer/index.html|access-date=12 June 2021|website=CNN|date=11 June 2021}}</ref> Each member's [[head of government]] or [[head of state|state]], along with the EU's [[President of the European Commission|Commission President]] and [[President of the European Council|European Council President]], meet annually at the G7 Summit; other high-ranking officials of the G7 and the EU meet throughout the year. Representatives of other states and international organizations are often invited as guests, with [[Russia]] having been a formal member (as part of the [[G8]]) from 1997 until its expulsion in 2014.

The G7 is not based on a treaty and has no permanent secretariat or office. It is organized through a presidency that rotates annually among the member states, with the presiding state setting the group's priorities and hosting the summit; Japan presides for 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Prime Minister's office of Japan |date=15 April 2023 |title=G7 Hiroshima Summit {{!}} Prime Minister's office of Japan |url=https://japan.kantei.go.jp/ongoingtopics/g7hiroshima_summit2023/index.html |access-date=15 April 2023}}</ref> While lacking a legal or institutional basis, the G7 is widely considered to wield significant international influence;<ref name="Shear">{{Cite news|last=Shear|first=Michael D.|date=11 June 2021|title=G7 News: A Return to Face-to-Face Diplomacy|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/06/11/world/g7-summit|access-date=12 June 2021|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> it has catalyzed or spearheaded several major global initiatives, including efforts to combat the [[HIV/AIDS pandemic]], provide financial aid to developing countries, and [[climate change mitigation|address climate change]] through the 2015 [[Paris Agreement]].<ref name="Shear"/><ref name="What is the G7"/><ref>{{Cite web|title=What are the G7 and the G8?|url=http://www.g8.utoronto.ca/what_is_g8.html|access-date=12 June 2021|website=www.g8.utoronto.ca}}</ref> However, the group has been criticized by observers for its allegedly outdated and limited membership, narrow global representation, and ineffectualness.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Meredith |first=Sam |title='The selfie summit': Why some economists and activists are disappointed with the G-7 |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/14/g-7-summit-why-economists-and-activists-are-disappointed-over-pledges.html |access-date=2022-11-09 |website=CNBC |date=14 June 2021 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Where Is the G7 Headed? |url=https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/where-g7-headed |access-date=2022-11-09 |website=Council on Foreign Relations |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=G-7 Communique Wide-Ranging, But Critics Find Shortcomings |url=https://www.voanews.com/a/europe_g-7-communique-wide-ranging-critics-find-shortcomings/6206982.html |access-date=2022-11-09 |website=VOA |date=13 June 2021 |language=en}}</ref>

==History==
=== Origins ===
The concept of a forum for the capitalist world's major [[industrialized countries]] emerged before the [[1973 oil crisis]]. On 25 March 1973, the [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]], [[George Shultz]], convened an informal gathering of [[finance ministers]] from West Germany ([[Helmut Schmidt]]), France ([[Valéry Giscard d'Estaing]]), and the United Kingdom ([[Anthony Barber]]) before an upcoming meeting in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington, DC]]. United States President [[Richard M. Nixon|Richard Nixon]] offered [[White House|the White House]] as a venue, and the meeting was subsequently held in its [[Library (White House)|library]] on the ground floor;<ref name="Schultz">Shultz, George P. (1993). ''Turmoil and Triumph: My Years as Secretary of State'' (Scribner's) p. 148. {{ISBN|0-684-19325-6}}.</ref> the original group of four consequently became known as the "Library Group".<ref>Bayne, Nicholas; Putnam, Robert D. (2000). ''Hanging in There''. Ashgate Pub Ltd. 230 pages. {{ISBN|075461185X}}. p. 20.</ref> In mid-1973, at the Spring Meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, Shultz proposed the addition of Japan, which all members accepted.<ref name="Schultz"/> The informal gathering of senior financial officials from the United States, United Kingdom, [[West Germany]], Japan, and France became known as the "Group of Five".<ref>Farnsworth, Clyde H. (8 May 1977). "A Secret Society of Finance Ministers", ''New York Times''.</ref>

In 1974, all five members endured sudden and often troubled changes in leadership. French President [[Georges Pompidou]] abruptly died, leading to a [[1974 French presidential election|fresh presidential election]] that was closely won by [[Valéry Giscard d'Estaing]]. West German Chancellor [[Willy Brandt]], American President [[Richard Nixon]], and Japanese Prime Minister [[Kakuei Tanaka]] all resigned due to scandals. In the United Kingdom, a [[February 1974 United Kingdom general election|hung election]] led to a minority government whose subsequent instability prompted [[October 1974 United Kingdom general election|another election the same year]]. Consequently, Nixon's successor, [[Gerald Ford]], proposed a retreat the following year for the group's new leaders to learn about one another.

=== First summit and expansion ===
[[File:Photograph of President Gerald R. Ford Meeting with Foreign Heads of State in the Salle des Marbres in the Chateau de Rambouillet at the International Economic Summit Conference in Rambouillet, France - NARA - 7518995.jpg|thumb|[[1st G6 summit|First G6 summit]] at the [[Chateau de Rambouillet]] in November 1975]]
At the initiative of [[Valéry Giscard d'Estaing|Giscard d'Estaing]] and his German counterpart, [[Helmut Schmidt]], France hosted [[1st G6 summit|a three-day summit in November 1975]], inviting the Group of Five plus Italy, forming the "Group of Six" (G6).<ref>{{Cite web|title=G7 summit {{!}} The history of the G7|url=https://www.g7germany.de/Content/EN/StatischeSeiten/G7_elmau_en/texte_en/2014-11-05-geschichte-g8.html#:~:text=The%20G7%20was%20born%20as%20a%20result%20of,and%20government%20to%20consult%20on%20international%20economic%20policy.|access-date=13 June 2021|website=www.g7germany.de}}</ref> Taking place at the [[Château de Rambouillet]], the meeting focused on several major economic issues, including the oil crisis, the collapse of the [[Bretton Woods system]], and the [[1973-1975 recession|ongoing global recession]].<ref name="evian">{{cite web|url=http://www.g8.fr/evian/english/navigation/the_g8/questions_about_the_g8.html#question1|title=Evian summit – Questions about the G8|publisher=Ministère des Affaires étrangères, Paris|access-date=18 March 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110420120547/http://www.g8.fr/evian/english/navigation/the_g8/questions_about_the_g8.html#question1|archive-date=20 April 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> The result was the 15-point "Declaration of Rambouillet", which, among other positions, announced the group's united commitment to promoting free trade, multilateralism, cooperation with the developing world, and rapprochement with the Eastern Bloc.<ref>{{Cite web|title=MOFA: Rambouillet Summit – Declaration of Rambouillet|url=https://www.mofa.go.jp/policy/economy/summit/2000/past_summit/01/e01_a.html#:~:text=DECLARATION%20OF%20RAMBOUILLET%20November%2017,%201975%20The%20heads,November%201975,%20and%20agreed%20to%20declare%20as%20follows:|access-date=13 June 2021|website=www.mofa.go.jp}}</ref> The members also established plans for future gatherings to take place regularly every year.

In 1976, British Prime Minister Harold Wilson, who had participated in the first G6 summit, resigned from office; Schmidt and [[Gerald Ford|Ford]] believed the group needed an English speaker with more political experience, and advocated for inviting [[Pierre Trudeau]], who had been Prime Minister of Canada for eight years{{snd}}significantly longer than any G6 leader. Canada was also the next largest advanced economy after the G6 members.<ref>[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/g8-the-most-exclusive-club-in-the-world-feature/ The Canadian Encyclopedia – Canada and the G8] ''G8: The Most Exclusive Club in the World'', Thomas S. Axworthy, ''The Canadian Encyclopedia'', Historica Foundation of Canada, Toronto, Undated. Retrieved 23 July 2015.</ref> The summit in Dorado, Puerto Rico later that year became the first of the current Group of Seven (G7).<ref name="evian" />

In 1977, the United Kingdom, which hosted that year's summit, invited the [[European Economic Community]] to join all G7 summits; beginning in 1981, it has attended every gathering through the [[president of the European Commission]] and the leader of the country holding the [[presidency of the Council of the European Union]].<ref name=deljpn20060717>{{cite web|url=http://www.deljpn.ec.europa.eu/union/showpage_en_union.Harry.g8.php |title=EU and the G8 |access-date=17 July 2006 |publisher=European Union |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071226041143/http://www.deljpn.ec.europa.eu/union/showpage_en_union.Harry.g8.php |archive-date=26 December 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Since 2009, the then-newly established position of the [[President of the European Council]], who serves as the Union's principal foreign representative, also regularly attends the summits.

=== Rising profile ===
[[File:G7 flags, Toronto.jpg|thumb|right|Flags of G7 members as seen on [[University Avenue (Toronto)|University Avenue]], [[Toronto]] (September 2016)]]
Until the 1985 [[Plaza Accord]], meetings between the seven governments' finance ministers were not public knowledge. The Accord, which involved only the original Group of Five, was announced the day before it was finalized, with a communiqué issued afterward.<ref>{{cite book|author=Schaefer, Robert K|chapter=Dollar Devaluations|title=Understanding Globalization: The Social Consequences of Political, Economic, and Environmental Change|year=2005|publisher=Rowman and Littlefield|page=346}}</ref> The 1980s also marked the G7's expanded concerns beyond macroeconomic issues, namely with respect to international security and conflict; for example, it sought to address the ongoing conflicts between Iran and Iraq and between the Soviet Union and Afghanistan.

Following [[20th G7 summit|the 1994 summit in Naples]], Russian officials held separate meetings with leaders of the G7. This informal arrangement was dubbed the "Political 8" (P8), colloquially the G7+1. At the invitation of the G7 leaders, Russian President [[Boris Yeltsin]] was invited first as a guest observer, and later as a full participant. After the 1997 meeting, Russia was formally invited to the next meeting and formally joined the group in 1998, resulting in the [[Group of Eight]] (G8).<ref name="evian" /> Russia was an outlier in the group, as it lacked the [[national wealth]] and financial weight of other members, had never been a major advanced economy, and was not yet an established liberal democracy.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2017/02/weodata/weoselgr.aspx|title=Select Country or Country Groups|website=www.imf.org}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://publications.credit-suisse.com/tasks/render/file/index.cfm?fileid=AD6F2B43-B17B-345E-E20A1A254A3E24A5 |title=Archived copy |access-date=9 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921085716/http://publications.credit-suisse.com/tasks/render/file/index.cfm?fileid=AD6F2B43-B17B-345E-E20A1A254A3E24A5 |archive-date=21 September 2017 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Its invitation, made during a [[Russian economy|difficult transition to a post-communist economy]], is believed to have been motivated by a desire to encourage its political and economic reforms and international engagement.

Russia's membership was suspended in March 2014 in response to its [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation of Crimea]].<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Smale |first1=Alison |last2=Shear |first2=Michael D. |date=24 March 2014 |title=Russia Is Ousted From Group of 8 by U.S. and Allies |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/25/world/europe/obama-russia-crimea.html |access-date=21 May 2023 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name="CNN.com2">{{cite news |date=24 March 2014 |title=U.S., other powers kick Russia out of G8 |publisher=CNN.com |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/03/24/politics/obama-europe-trip/index.html |access-date=21 May 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=24 March 2014 |title=Russia suspended from G8 over annexation of Crimea, Group of Seven nations says |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/03/24/there-is-no-g8-russia-suspended-from-exclusive-club-until-it-changes-course-group-of-seven-nations-says/ |access-date=21 December 2015 |work=National Post}}</ref> Members stopped short of permanently ejecting the country,<ref>{{Cite web |date=25 March 2014 |title=Ukraine crisis: Russia is scathing about its G8 suspension |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-crisis-g-7-leaders-cancel-g-8-summit-sochi-until-russia-changes-course-9213000.html |access-date=13 June 2021 |website=The Independent |language=en}}</ref> and in subsequent years expressed an openness or express desire to reinstate Russian participation. In January 2017, Russia announced it would permanently leave the G8, which came into effect June 2018.<ref name="russia-suspension2">{{Cite web |date=13 January 2017 |title=Russia just quit the G8 for good |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/russia-g8-kremlin-crimea-ukraine-vladimir-putin-g7-g20-a7525836.html |website=The Independent}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=9 June 2018 |title=Russia brushes off possibility of G-8 return |newspaper=The Straits Times |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/russia-brushes-off-possibility-of-g-8-return}}</ref> In 2020, U.S. President [[Donald Trump]], backed by Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, advocated for Russia's return; all other members rejected the proposal, and Russia expressed no interest.<ref>{{Cite web|last=hermesauto|date=9 June 2018|title=Russia brushes off possibility of G-8 return|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/russia-brushes-off-possibility-of-g-8-return|access-date=13 June 2021|website=The Straits Times|language=en}}</ref>

== Renewed calls for expanded membership ==
There have been various proposals to expand the G7. The U.S.-based Atlantic Council has held the [[D-10 Strategy Forum]] since 2014 with representatives from what it calls "leading democracies" which support a "rules-based democratic order", consisting of all members of the G7 (including the [[European Union]]) plus [[Australia]] and [[South Korea]]. Several democratic countries{{snd}}including [[India]], [[Indonesia]], [[Poland]], and [[Spain]]{{snd}} participate as observers.<ref name="auto1" /> Centered around a similar mandate as the G7, the D-10 has been considered by some analysts to be an alternative to the group;<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title=Forget the G-7 – Biden needs a D-10 to rally the democracies|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/forget-the-g7-biden-needs-a-d-10-to-rally-the-democracies/ar-AAKWD4i|access-date=15 June 2021|website=www.msn.com}}</ref> This is also favored by various [[think tank]]s and former [[Boris Johnson|British leader Boris Johnson]].<ref name="auto1">{{cite web | url = https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/programs/scowcroft-center-for-strategy-and-security/global-strategy-initiative/democratic-order-initiative/d-10-strategy-forum/ | title = D-10 Strategy Forum | publisher = Atlantic Council | language = }}</ref>

In 2019 under [[Vladimir Putin|Putin]], [[Russia]] had signaled support for the inclusion of [[China]], India, and [[Turkey]] if the G7 had reinstated Russian membership.<ref>{{cite news |title=Russia suggests Turkey to be part of G7 |url=https://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/russia-suggests-turkey-to-be-part-of-g7-146320 |access-date = 20 December 2021 |work=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date= 5 September 2019 |language=en}}</ref>

In 2020 under [[Donald Trump|Trump]], the U.S. had signaled support for the inclusion of Australia, [[Brazil]], India, and South Korea, plus the reincorporation of Russia.<ref>{{cite news |title=Donald Trump postpones G7 summit and signals wider invitation list |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/may/31/donald-trump-postpones-g7-summit-and-signals-wider-attendance-list-in-future |access-date=31 May 2020 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=31 May 2020 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.outlookindia.com/newsscroll/spoke-with-trump-about-entry-into-expanded-g7-bolsonaro/1853175|title=Spoke with Trump about entry into expanded G7: Bolsonaro|work = [[The Outlook (Gresham)|The Outlook]] |access-date = 2 June 2020}}</ref> The leaders of the other six G7 members unanimously rejected this proposal.<ref>{{cite news |title=G7 leaders reject Russia's return after Trump summit invite |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-52885178 |work=[[BBC]] |date=2 June 2020 |access-date=6 June 2023}}</ref>

Also in November 2020, [[Jared Cohen]] and [[Richard Fontaine]], writing in [[Foreign Affairs]], suggested that the G7 might be expanded to a "T-12" of "Techno Democracies". Earlier, in June of that same year, the [[Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence]] (GPAI) was announced. Something of a spin-out of the G7, founded by members Canada and France, GPAI's initial membership was 15, including both the EU and India, as well as Australia, Mexico, New Zealand, Singapore, Slovenia, and the Republic of Korea.

Boris Johnson invited members of Australia and the Republic of Korea to the June 2021 G7 summit.<ref name=":0" /> India was also invited to the 2021 summit, with an aim to "deepen the expertise and experience around the table" along with the other guests, according to a U.K. government statement.<ref name="Ellyatt">{{Cite web|last=Ellyatt|first=Holly|date=10 June 2021|title=G-7 summit: Here's a quick guide to everything you need to know|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/10/the-g-7-summit-guide-to-everything-you-need-to-know.html|access-date=15 June 2021|website=CNBC|language=en}}</ref>

In 2021, French jurist and consultant Eric Garner de Béville, a member of the ''Cercle Montesquieu'', proposed Spain's membership to the G7.<ref>{{cite news |title=L'Espagne peut-elle intégrer le G7 |url=https://www.challenges.fr/tribunes/l-espagne-peut-elle-integrer-le-g7_753386 |date=2 March 2021 |work=[[Challenges (magazine)|Challenges]] |language=fr}}</ref> American Chargé d'Affaires in Spain, Conrad Tribble, stated that the United States "enthusiastically supports" a "greater" role of Spanish leadership at the international level.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.europapress.es/internacional/noticia-estados-unidos-apoya-entusiasmo-mayor-liderazgo-espana-nivel-internacional-20210325183824.html | title=Estados Unidos "apoya con entusiasmo" un "mayor" liderazgo de España a nivel internacional |date=25 February 2021 |work=[[Europa Press (news agency)|Europa Press]]| language=es}}</ref>

In 2022, Germany has confirmed it will be inviting India,<ref>{{Cite web |title=India invited by Germany for G7 summit in June |url=https://www.wionews.com/india-news/india-invited-by-germany-for-g7-summit-in-june-470657 |access-date=21 April 2022 |website=WION |language=en}}</ref> against rumours to the contrary.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-04-12/germany-may-snub-india-as-g-7-guest-over-russia-stance |title=Germany Weighs Snubbing India as G-7 Guest Over Russia Stance |work=Bloomberg |last1=Nardelli |first1=Alberto |last2=Nienaber |first2=Michael |date=12 April 2022 |access-date=20 April 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Chaudhury |first=Dipanjan Roy |title=Germany isn't considering India's exclusion from G-7 guest list: Source |work=The Economic Times |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/india/germany-isnt-considering-indias-exclusion-from-g-7-guest-list-source/articleshow/90833144.cms |access-date=21 April 2022}}</ref>{{update after|2022}}<!-- was India actually invited? if so, a better/later source and changing the prose to clarify that would be in order -->

The G7 was founded primarily to facilitate shared macroeconomic initiatives in response to contemporary economic problems; the first gathering was centered around the [[Nixon shock]], the [[1970s energy crisis]], and the ensuing global recession.<ref name=Bayne>{{Citation|publisher = Routledge|isbn = 9780415164863|ol = 7484858M|chapter = International economic organizations : more policy making less autonomy|title = Autonomous Policymaking By International Organizations (Routledge/Ecpr Studies in European Political Science, 5)| last  = Bayne| first = Nicholas| editor1-last = Reinalda| editor1-first = Bob| editor2-last = Verbeek| editor2-first = Bertjan|date = 1998|oclc = 70763323|id = 0415164869}}</ref> Since 1975, the group has met annually at summits organized and hosted by whichever country occupies the annually-rotating presidency;<ref name="g7germany.de">{{Cite web|title=G7 summit {{!}} The history of the G7|url=https://www.g7germany.de/Content/EN/StatischeSeiten/G7_elmau_en/texte_en/2014-11-05-geschichte-g8.html#:~:text=The%20G7%20was%20born%20as%20a%20result%20of,and%20government%20to%20consult%20on%20international%20economic%20policy.|access-date=15 June 2021|website=www.g7germany.de}}</ref> since 1987, the G7 Finance Ministers have met at least semi-annually, and up to four times a year at stand-alone meetings.<ref name="meet">{{cite web|title=G7/8 Ministerial Meetings and Documents|url=http://www.g8.utoronto.ca/meetings.html|work=G8 Information Centre|publisher=University of Toronto|access-date=14 March 2014|year=2014}}</ref>

Beginning in the 1980s, the G7 broadened its areas of concern to include issues of international security, human rights, and global security; for example, during this period, the G7 concerned itself with the ongoing [[Iran–Iraq War|Iran-Iraq War]] and [[Soviet–Afghan War|Soviet occupation of Afghanistan]].<ref name="g7germany.de"/> In the 1990s, it launched a debt-relief program for the 42 [[heavily indebted poor countries]] (HIPC);<ref>{{cite web|title=Debt Relief Under the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative;Perspectives on the Current Framework and Options for Change|url=http://www.imf.org/external/np/hipc/options/|author=International Money Fund|publisher=IMF.org|access-date=25 March 2014}}</ref> provided $300 million to help build the [[Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant sarcophagus|Shelter Structure]] over [[Chernobyl disaster|the damaged reactor at Chernobyl]];<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/5255663/chernobyl-disaster-book-anniversary/|title=The True Cost of the Chernobyl Disaster Has Been Greater Than It Seems|date=26 April 2018|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|access-date=22 February 2019}}</ref> and established the [[Financial Stability Forum]] to help in "managing the international monetary system".<ref name="Van" />

At the turn of the 21st century, the G7 began emphasizing engagement with the developing world. At the 1999 summit, the group helped launch the [[G20]], a similar forum made up of the G7 and the next 13 largest economies (including the European Union), in order to "promote dialogue between major industrial and emerging market countries";<ref name="Van">{{cite web|last=Van Houtven|first=Leo|title=Rethinking IMF Governance |url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/fandd/2004/09/pdf/vanhoutv.pdf|work=Finance & Development|publisher=International Money Fund|access-date=25 March 2014|page=18|date=September 2004}}</ref> the G20 has been touted by some of its members as a replacement for the G7.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Officials: G-20 to supplant G-8 as international economic council |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/09/24/us.g.twenty.summit/index.html|access-date=15 June 2021|website=www.cnn.com}}</ref> Having previously announced a plan to cancel 90% of bilateral debt for the HIPC, totaling $100 billion, in 2005 the G7 announced debt reductions of "up to 100%" to be negotiated on a "case by case" basis.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4238045.stm|title=G7 backs Africa debt relief plan|date=5 February 2005|via=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>

In response to Russia's subsequent [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexation]] of [[Crimea]], on 24 March the G7 convened an emergency meeting at the official residence of the [[Prime Minister of the Netherlands]], the [[Catshuis]] in [[The Hague]]; this location was chosen because all G7 leaders were already present to attend the [[2014 Nuclear Security Summit]] hosted by the Netherlands. This was the first G7 meeting neither taking place in a member state nor having the host leader participating in the meeting.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/g7-leaders-descend-on-the-netherlands-for-ukraine-crisis-talks-1.2583287|title=G7 leaders descend on the Netherlands for Ukraine crisis talks|newspaper=CBC news|publisher=Thomson Reuters|date=23 March 2014}}</ref> The upcoming G8 summit in [[Sochi|Sochi, Russia]] was moved to Brussels, where the EU was the host. On 5 June 2014 the G7 condemned Moscow for its "continuing violation" of Ukraine's sovereignty and stated they were prepared to impose further sanctions on Russia.<ref name="bbc201406">{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27707518 | title = G7 leaders warn Russia of fresh sanctions over Ukraine | author=BBC|publisher=BBC|date = 5 June 2014}}</ref> This meeting was the first since Russia was suspended from the G8,<ref name="bbc201406" /> and subsequently it has not been involved in any G7 summit.

The G7 has continued to take a strong stance against Russia's "destabilising behaviour and malign activities" in Ukraine and elsewhere around the world, following the joint communique from the June 2021 summit in the U.K.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|agency=Reuters|date=13 June 2021|title=G7 Demand Action From Russia on Cybercrimes and Chemical Weapon Use|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-06-13/g7-demand-action-from-russia-on-cybercrimes-and-chemical-weapon-use}}</ref> The group also called on Russia to address international cybercrime attacks launched from within its borders, and to investigate the use of chemical weapons on Russian opposition leader [[Alexei Navalny]].<ref name=":1" /> The June 2021 summit also saw the G7 commit to helping the world recover from the [[COVID-19 pandemic|global COVID-19 pandemic]] (including plans to help vaccinate the entire world); encourage further action against climate change and biodiversity loss; and promote "shared values" of pluralism and democracy.<ref name="Ellyatt"/>

In 2022, G7 leaders were invited to attend an [[2022 Brussels extraordinary summit|extraordinary summit of NATO]] called in response to the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite news |title=NATO hosts meeting of G7 Leaders |url=https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/photos_193850.htm?selectedLocale=en |date=24 March 2022 |language=en |work=[[NATO]] |access-date=25 March 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=NATO hosts meeting of G7 Leaders (revised) |url=https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_193670.htm |date=24 March 2022 |language=en |work=[[NATO]] |access-date=25 March 2022 }}</ref>

=== Summit organization ===
The annual G7 summit is attended by each member's head of government.<ref name="feldman1">{{cite journal |last=Feldman |first=Adam |url=https://www.forbes.com/opinions/2008/07/05/problems-unity-progress-oped-cx_af_summit08_0707feldman.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080803031809/http://www.forbes.com/opinions/2008/07/05/problems-unity-progress-oped-cx_af_summit08_0707feldman.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=3 August 2008 |title=What's Wrong with the G-8 |journal=Forbes |location=New York |date=7 July 2008}}</ref> The member country holding the G7 presidency is responsible for organizing and hosting the year's summit. The serial annual summits can be parsed chronologically in arguably distinct ways, including as the sequence of host countries for the summits has recurred over time and series.<ref>Hajnal, Peter I. (1999). {{Google books|Bi5JO7FFk7UC|''The G8 System and the G20: Evolution, Role and Documentation'', p. 30.|page=30}}</ref> Generally every country hosts the summit once every seven years.<ref>[http://www.g7italy.it/cose-g7 G7 Italy 2017], Italian official website, 2017</ref>

Besides a main meeting in June or July, a number of other meetings may take place throughout the year; in 2021 for example, seven tracks existed for finance (4–5 June 2021), environmental (20 and 21 May 2021), health (3–4 June 2021), trade (27–28 May 2021), interior (7–9 September 2021) digital and technology (28–29 April 2021), development (3–5 May 2021) and foreign ministers.<ref name="ministers">{{Cite web |date=2021 |title=Ministerial Meetings & Engagement Groups |url=https://www.g7uk.org/ministerial-meetings-engagement-groups/ |access-date=10 December 2021 |website=G7 UK Presidency 2021 |language=en-GB |archive-date=10 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211210213243/https://www.g7uk.org/ministerial-meetings-engagement-groups/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>

==Criticisms and controversies==

===2015 protests===
{{further|41st G7 summit}}
About 7,500 protesters led by the group 'Stop-G7' demonstrated during the summit. About 300 of those reached the 3 m high and 7 km long security fence surrounding the summit location. The protesters questioned the legitimacy of the G7 to make decisions that could affect the whole world. Authorities had banned demonstrations in the area closest to the summit location and 20,000 police were on duty in Southern Bavaria to keep activists and protesters from interfering with the summit.<ref name=Spiegel07June>{{cite news|title=Der Spiegel: Proteste um Schloss Elmau – Demonstranten wandern bis zum G7-Zaun.|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/g7-gipfel-protestzug-erreicht-zaun-um-schloss-elmau-a-1037560.html|access-date=11 June 2015|newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=Bild03June>{{cite news|title=Bild: 7 Kilometer lang, 3 Meter hoch, auf ganzer Länge beleuchtet.|url=http://www.bild.de/regional/muenchen/g7-gipfel/mit-hohem-sicherheitsaufgebot-41201204.bild.html|access-date=11 June 2015|newspaper=[[Bild]]|date=3 June 2015}}</ref>

===2018 Trump conflict over tariffs and Russia===
{{further|44th G7 summit|Russo-Ukrainian War}}
The [[44th G7 summit|2018 meeting in Charlevoix, Canada]], was marred by fractious negotiations concerning tariffs and Donald Trump's position that Russia should be reinstated to the G7. The Trump administration had just imposed steel and aluminium tariffs on many countries, including European countries that are fellow members of the G7, and Canada, the host country for the 2018 meeting. Trump expressed dismay at Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for holding a press conference in which Canada restated its position on tariffs (a public criticism of Trump's economic policy), and directed his representatives at the meeting not to sign the economic section of the joint communiqué that is typically issued at the conclusion of the meeting.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel described Trump's behaviour as a "depressing withdrawal", while French President Emmanuel Macron invited him "to be serious".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://tg24.sky.it/mondo/2018/06/10/g7-canada-trump.html|title=G7, Trump non-accetta il documento finale. Merkel: "Ritiro deprimente" – Sky TG24|language=it}}</ref> In the final statement signed by all members except the US, the G7 announced its intention to recall sanctions and to be ready to take further restrictive measures within the next months against the Russian Federation for its failure to completely implement the [[Minsk Agreement]].<ref name="auto" />

Trump repeated calls for Russia to be re-admitted to the group at the 2019 meeting in Biarritz, saying it should be included in discussions relating to Iran, Syria, and North Korea. The Italian Prime Minister [[Giuseppe Conte]] supported Trump's proposal, [[Shinzo Abe]] of Japan was neutral, and the rest of the G7 pushed back against the suggestion, after which the atmosphere allegedly became "tense". {{citation needed|date=August 2021}}

=== 2019 Amazon rainforest fires and Brazil ===
{{further|45th G7 summit|2019 Brazil wildfires}}
U.S. President [[Donald Trump]]'s reiteration that Russia should be readmitted to the group (see above), the instigation of a [[trade war]] with China, increased tensions in Iran, Trump's alleged reluctance to attend the conference, and a number of international crises made the 2019 G7 meeting in [[Biarritz]], France, the most divided since its inception. Following President Trump's previous revocation of his signature to a joint communiqué agreed to in 2018 due to an alleged slight from Canadian Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] (see above), French President [[Emmanuel Macron]] agreed that the group would not issue a joint communiqué at the Biarritz conference.

The G7 nations pledged US$20 million to help Brazil and other countries in South America fight the wildfires. This money was welcomed, although it was widely seen as a "relatively small amount" given the scale of the problem. Macron threatened to block a major trade deal between the European Union and Brazil ([[Mercosur]]) that would benefit the agricultural interests accused of driving deforestation. Soon after, Germany and the United Kingdom criticized the threat.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-g7-summit-mercosur-idUSKCN1VE0ON/| title=Britain joins Germany in criticizing Macron's Mercosur threat| publisher=Thomson Reuters| date=25 August 2019| access-date=30 December 2023}}</ref>
